Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Hawaiian and Subplinian Basaltic Volcanism: Constraints on Eruption Dynamics from Kilauea
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the forces controlling basaltic explosive eruptions is of fundamental importance in order to improve understanding of the range of behaviors of our most frequently active volcanoes and to assess hazards of future explosive events. The summit of Kîlauea is the site of large and growing volcano-tourism (e.g., 5000 visitors/day at the overlook at Jaggar Museum), and there is a public need both for better knowledge of the volcanoes' behavior and improved forecasting of the likely course of future eruptions. Although not its usual style, explosive eruptions have punctuated Kîlauea's history, with five moderately large events since 1500 CE.

The study quantifies and models the dominant factors that determine explosive eruptive behavior at Kilauea volcano, through a study of the eruptive products from three plume-forming and fountaining eruptions. The events are episode 1 of the highest historical fountaining eruption at Kîlauea, the 1959 Kîlauea Iki eruption, a much earlier powerful fountaining eruption in 1480 CE and a powerful; plume-forming eruption in 1635 CE.

The novelty of the approach lies in using new 'rate-meters' to estimate likely durations of magma ascent beneath the volcano to arrive at the influence of this residence time on the ultimate 'fate' of the magma. The investigators will study microtextures (vesicles and microlites), volatiles in melt inclusions, and embayments in eruptive products.

In addition to direct support for 3 graduate students and undergraduate students, results will contribute to educational outreach efforts anchored on development of volcanology classes at University of Hawaii, Columbia University and Rice University. The proposal involves exchange of material and ideas between five institutions to the benefit of young researchers, and undergraduate and graduate classes. Our results will be widely disseminated via the Internet using linked web sites hosted by Hawaiian Volcano Observatory and NSF-funded institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During a volcanic eruption magma flows from a storage reservoir at several kilometers depth through a conduit to the surface. The style and intensity with which the magma erupts onto the surface depends on the conditions of magma ascent, which are inaccessible to direct observation, and have to be inferred from indirect measurements and numerical modeling. The goal of this project is to provide new insights on magma ascent conditions during explosive eruptions of different style and intensity at Earth's most active volcano, Kilauea, Hawaii. The project integrates the analysis of pyroclastic samples from these eruptions with numerical modeling of the ascent conditions recorded by the samples.

Kilauea is best known for almost continuous eruptive activity since the early 1980s, most of which has been non-explosive. However, Kilauea also erupts explosively, typically producing up to 500 meter tall fountains of fragmented magma, these are called Hawaiian fire fountain eruptions. More importantly, it has recently been discovered that in the past Kilauea has had far more intense explosive subplinian eruptions, which eject volcanic gases and ash as more than 10 kilometer tall columns into the Earth's atmosphere. It is realistic to expect that such powerful eruptions may occur again in the future. The underlying conditions for such intense eruptions are not well understood. Addressing this shortcoming is the motivation for this project. Two million people visit Kilauea every year. Even small eruptions have a significant impact on Hawaii Volcanoes National Park, surrounding communities, and the State of Hawaii. Consequently, new insights gained through this project are of societal relevance.

This project is focused on one of the key conditions of eruptive magma ascent, the rate at which the pressure to which the magma is subjected decreases, which is called the decompression rate. At depth magma is stored prior to eruption at pressures of the order of 1000 atmospheres, due to the weight of the overlying rock. Under these conditions the magma contains an abundance of dissolved magmatic gases, such as water, sulfur and carbon dioxide. The solubility of these gases depends on pressure. As the magma ascends to surface both pressure and solubility decrease. As a consequence the gases form bubbles within the ascending magma. Because of the low density of the gases within the bubbles, the magma gains buoyancy. At the same time, the large compressibility of the gases may cause bubbles to remain at a high pressure while the magma ascends to lower pressures. This increases the propensity for explosive expansion of the magma, as it approaches or upon reaching the surface. During such explosive expansion the magma is torn into small pieces called pyroclasts. The possibility or intensity of such an explosive eruption is expected to depend on the speed at which magma ascends, which in turn affects the decompression rate. 

This project estimates decompression rates for three different explosive eruptions at Kilauea: the Keanakakoi fountain eruption from approximately 1500 CE; the Keanakakoi subplinian eruption from approximately 1635 CE; and the Kilauea Iki fountain eruption from the year 1959. The project encompasses sophisticated microns-size concentration measurements of dissolved gases within small tubules of melt, now quenched to glass, which became entrapped prior to eruption within growing olivine crystals.
